case_name: Heirs of Venkanna v. Venkata Sattayya

facts.text: Ramamurti died childless in the year 1908 leaving behind his widow Narasimham.

anchor.surface_text: Venkanna, the father of the appellants, had a brother Ramamurti who died childless in the year 1908 leaving behind him his widow Narasimham.

facts.text: Venkanna filed O.S. No. 14 of 1913 against the widow Narasimham in respect of acts of waste committed by her of Ramamurti's estate.

anchor.surface_text: After Ramamurtis death a series of litigations started between Venkanna and Narasimham and it is number over yet. Venkanna filed O.S. No. 14 of 1913 against the widow in respect of acts of waste companymitted by her of Ramamurtis estate

facts.text: Venkanna was appointed a receiver in O.S. No. 14 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: ...acts of waste companymitted by her of Ramamurtis estate and was appointed a receiver in that suit.

facts.text: Venkanna got a decree against Narasimham for Rs.13,539/- in O.S. No. 14 of 1913 as she failed to furnish security.

anchor.surface_text: ...and was appointed a receiver in that suit. In that suit he got a decree against Narasimham for a sum of Rs.13,539/- as she failed to furnish security as originally decreed by the companyrt.

facts.text: Venkanna as receiver filed O.S. No. 34 of 1916 on the foot of a mortgage in favour of Ramamurti.

anchor.surface_text: Venkanna as receiver filed three suits on the foot of three mortgages in favour of Ramamurti. One was O. S. No. 34 of 1916.

facts.text: In execution of decree in O.S. No. 34 of 1916, item 1 of the A Schedule properties was purchased in court auction.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of that decree item 1 of the A Schedule properties was purchased in companyrt auction.

facts.text: O.S. No. 443 of 1918 was filed on the foot of another mortgage in favour of Ramamurti executed in 1904.

anchor.surface_text: O.S. No. 443 of 1918 was filed on the, foot of another mortgage in favour of Ramamurti executed in 1904

facts.text: Items 2 and 5 of the plaint schedule properties were purchased in execution of decree in O.S. No. 443 of 1918.

anchor.surface_text: and items 2 and 5 of the plaint schedule properties were purchased in execution of decree in that suit.

facts.text: Items 1, 2 and 5 are the subject matter of this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: These three items of properties are the subject matter of this appeal.

facts.text: Venkanna died in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Venkanna died in 1947 and Narasimham in 1951

facts.text: Narasimham died in 1951 after executing a will bequeathing all her properties to her brother Venkata Sattayya.

anchor.surface_text: Venkanna died in 1947 and Narasimham in 1951 after executing a will bequeathing in favour of her brother Venkata Sattayya all her properties.

facts.text: Venkata Sattayya filed suit for possession of the properties bequeathed to him under the will and for mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: Venkata Sattayya filed the suit, out of which this appeal arises, for possession of the properties bequeathed to him under the will and for mesne profits.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held that items 1, 2 and 5 became accretions to the main estate of Ramamurti and plaintiff entitled only to account of income till death of Venkanna.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge who tried the suit held that items 1, 2 and 5 become accretions to the main estate of Ramamurti and therefore the plaintiff was entitled only to an account of the income from those properties till the death of Venkanna.

facts.text: Appeal against Subordinate Judge's judgment in A.S. No. 508 of 1959 before Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and Decree dated the 21st September 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. No. 508 of 1959.

facts.text: High Court judgment and decree dated 21st September 1965.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and Decree dated the 21st September 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. No. 508 of 1959.

facts.text: High Court called for finding on interest on two mortgages before and after Ramamurti's death.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges called for a finding with regard to the interest on the two mortgages in execution of the decrees in which items 1, 2 and 5 had been purchased, relating to he period before Ramamurtis death and the period after Ramamurtis death.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeal in part: plaintiff entitled to 19/34th share of item 1, and 12/23rd share of items 2 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: After that finding was received they allowed the appeal in part and held that the plaintiff would be entitled to a 19/34th share of item 1, and 12/23rd share of items 2 and 5.

facts.text: This appeal is Civil Appeal No. 1817 of 1967 pursuant to certificate by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1817 of 1967. From the judgment and Decree dated the 21st September 1965

facts.text: Out of item 1 (about 16 acres), 5 acres lost in revenue sale due to Narasimham's failure to pay land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Out of about 16 acres companyprised in item 1, 5 acres had been lost in revenue sale because of Narasimhams failure to pay the land revenue on those lands.

facts.text: Even when Venkanna died, Rs.4,486/- was due to him on foot of decree against Narasimham.

anchor.surface_text: We have also evidence in this case that even When Venkanna died a sum of Rs.4,486/- was due.to him on the foot of the decree he obtained against Narasimham.

facts.text: Narasimham claimed set off of amounts due to her and execution proceeded only for balance, claim allowed per Ex. A-7.

anchor.surface_text: We find from the finding submitted by the Trial Court  Page 86 of the paper book  Narasimham claimed that the amounts due to her should be set off and execution should proceed only for the balance and from Ex. A-7 it would appear that the claim was allowed.

facts.text: Venkanna submitted accounts as receiver till 1940.

anchor.surface_text: We find that Venkanna had submitted accounts to the companyrt in his capacity as receiver till 1940.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment and remands for fresh disposal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court set aside. The High Court will dispose of the appeal afresh.

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu widow is entitled to the full beneficial enjoyment of the estate. So long as she is number guilty of willful waste, she is answerable to numberone. Her estate is number a life- estate, because in certain circumstances she can give an absolute and companyplete title. Nor is it in any sense an estate held in trust for reversions.

concepts.interpretation: Widow has absolute power of enjoyment within limits, not a trustee for reversioners; not liable for losses due to negligence unless willful waste; reversioners get only what is left at her death.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: SDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1817 of 1967. From the judgment and Decree dated the 21st September 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. No. 508 of

arguments.court_reasoning: Set aside entire judgment; remand for fresh disposal considering all issues.

arguments.claim: Under Order XLI Rule 25 CPC, after receiving findings on referred issues, appellate court must hear entire appeal, not confine to those points; parties not barred from other arguments.

anchor.surface_text: We think that he is right in this contention. Before the High Court the learned advocate for the appellants had contended... We consider that when a finding is called for on the basis of certain issues framed by the Appellate Court the appeal is not disposed of either in whole or in part.

arguments.claim: Hindu widow has full beneficial enjoyment, not life estate or trustee; not liable for negligence/losses unless willful waste proven in suit by reversioner.

anchor.surface_text: A Hindu widow is entitled to the full beneficial enjoyment of the estate. So long as she is not guilty of willful waste, she is answerable to noone. Her estate is not a life- estate...

arguments.claim: Presumption that Hindu widow retains dominion over property bought from estate income; no accretion unless contrary intention.

anchor.surface_text: As observed by the Madras High Court in Akkanna v. Venkayya I.L.R. 1902 25 Mad. 351 the acquirer of property presumably intends to retain dominion over it and in the case of a Hindu widow the presumption is nonetheless so when the fund...

arguments.claim: High Court erred in disallowing set-off argument post-findings.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges disallowed him from raising that question on the ground that it was not raised or argued at the time when the finding was called for...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: al after the findings are received from the companyrt of first instance. We find the same view taken in Gopi Nath Shukul Sat Narain Shukul  AIR 1923 A

arguments.court_reasoning: Incorrect; whole appeal arguable under R25.

holdings.text: Under Order XLI Rule 25 CPC, when an appellate court frames issues and calls for findings from the lower court, the appeal is not disposed of in whole or in part, and parties cannot be barred from arguing the whole appeal after receipt of findings; distinguishing from remand under Rule 23.

anchor.surface_text: under Order XLI Rule 25 of the Code of Civil Procedure and number remanded the whole case under Order XII Rule 23, they should have heard the whole appeal and number companyfined the hearing merely to the points on which the finding was called for. We think that he is right in this companytention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred by confining hearing to referred issues; cites precedents from Allahabad (Gopi Nath), Nagpur (Sultan Beg), Calcutta (Abinash Chandra) holding R25 order not final, full hearing required post-findings.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in disallowing argument on set-off of mortgage interest against decree debt; this issue is admissible post-findings under O41 R25 and should be decided, as evidence (accounts till 1940, Ex A-7, balance due Rs.4486) suggests set-off likely occurred.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges disallowed him from raising that question on the ground that it was number raised or argued at the time when the finding was called for... We consider that when a finding is called for on the basis of certain issues framed by the Appellate Court the appeal is number disposed of either in whole or in part.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies same R25 principle; evidence from decree direction, receiver accounts, execution order (Ex A-7) indicates credits given to Narasimham, likely including interest; no final decision but directs consideration.

holdings.text: Narasimham's failure to pay land revenue leading to revenue sale loss of 5 acres from item 1 cannot be debited against her share; Hindu widow not liable for negligence or losses unless guilty of willful waste established in a suit by reversioners, which was not done here.

anchor.surface_text: Out of about 16 acres companyprised in item 1, 5 acres had been lost in revenue sale because of Narasimhams failure to pay the land revenue on those lands. It was urged before the High Court and it has been urged again before us that in allotting to the appellants a share of items 1, 2 and 5 these 5 acre-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Widow entitled to full beneficial enjoyment, not a trustee or strict life-estate holder; accountable only for willful waste via specific suit; reversioners take estate as left at death; no such suit or averments.

holdings.text: Costs incurred by Venkanna in suits and executions were already taken into account in settlement of accounts leading to executable decree for Rs.4,486/-; not open to appellants to claim separate adjustment in allocating shares.

anchor.surface_text: Another point urged before the High Court as well as before us was that the companyt incurred by Venkanna in the suit and in the execution proceedings should have been taken into account in allocating items 1, 2 and 5 between the appellants and the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accounts settled with inclusion of income/expenses; balance decree executable against estate; separate claim barred.

holdings.text: Narasimham did not treat items 1,2,5 as accretions to husband's estate by conduct; presumption that widow retains dominion over investments of income unless contrary intention shown; silence in executions advantageous, not estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was argued that Narasimham, the widow, had treated this property as accretion to the husbands estate and therefore the appellants are entitled to the whole of the property. The facts on the basis of which this companytention is urged are When Narasimhams life interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Madras HC Akkanna v. Venkayya (1902): presumption of retention of dominion over income investments; conduct (no objection to life interest sales) self-serving; widow's actions showed intent to benefit brother, not accrete.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and decree set aside; matter remanded for fresh disposal of appeal considering all issues including set-off.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court set aside. The High Court will dispose of the appeal afresh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural error primary; directs comprehensive rehearing.

precedents.citation: Gopi Nath Shukul Sat Narain Shukul  AIR 1923 Allahabad 384

anchor.surface_text: Gopi Nath Shukul Sat Narain Shukul  AIR 1923 Allahabad 384

precedents.case_name: Gopi Nath Shukul v. Sat Narain Shukul
precedents.cited_proposition: An appellate court which remits specific issues under Order XLI Rule 25 CPC does not dispose of the appeal and can hear the whole appeal after receipt of findings, disregarding previous views if necessary.
precedents.cited_holding: Where an appellate Court at the first hearing does number decide the case but merely remits certain specific issues, it is open to the Court before which the case ultimately companyes to disregard the findings on those issues and equally to form its own opinion on the whole case irrespective of anything that is said in the remand order. An order remanding issues under Rule 25 is number a final order.

precedents.citation: Sultan Beg Al. chunilal  AIR 1918 Nagpur 193

anchor.surface_text: Sultan Beg Al. chunilal  AIR 1918 Nagpur 193

precedents.cited_proposition: Similar view to the Allahabad case regarding the effect of remitting issues under Order XLI Rule 25 CPC.

precedents.citation: Abinash Chandra Bidyanidhi Bhattacharjee v. Dasarath Malo  XXXII  1927-28  Calcutta Weekly Notes 1233

anchor.surface_text: Abinash Chandra Bidyanidhi Bhattacharjee v. Dasarath Malo  XXXII  1927-28  Calcutta Weekly Notes 1233

precedents.case_name: Abinash Chandra Bidyanidhi Bhattacharjee v. Dasarath Malo
precedents.cited_proposition: An order remanding issues under Order 41 Rule 25 CPC decides nothing and the appellate court can go back on the reasons in the remand order when finally hearing the appeal.
precedents.cited_holding: An order of remand made under Or. 41, r. 25 decides numberhing. The Court, either the same or as differently companystituted, has jurisdiction, while finally hearing the appeal, to go back on the reasons given or views expressed in the order of remand and must do so when those appear erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: Akkanna v. Venkayya  I.L.R.  1902  25 Mad. 351

precedents.cited_proposition: A Hindu widow is presumed to intend to retain dominion over property acquired with income from her husband's estate, treating it as her separate property rather than accretion.
precedents.cited_holding: the acquirer of property presumably intends to retain dominion over it and in the case of a Hindu widow the presumption is numbere the less so when the fund with which the property is acquired is one which, though derived from her husbands property, was at her absolute disposal.
